byline.original: By ABBY GOODNOUGH and KEVIN SACK
byline.contributor: Abby Goodnough reported from Boston, and Kevin Sack from Atlanta.

abstract: Massachusetts, having passed landmark health legislation in 2006, is looking to become the first state to radically change how health care providers are paid; Gov Deval Patrick and lawmakers are working toward plan that replaces fee-for-service system with one that would encourage flat 'global payments' to networks of providers for keeping patients well.
snippet: After passing a landmark health bill, Massachusetts is now looking to become the first state to radically change the way health care providers are paid.
lead_paragraph: After passing a landmark health bill, Massachusetts is now looking to become the first state to radically change the way health care providers are paid.

headline.main: Massachusetts Tries to Rein In Its Health Costs
